verses.text: Do not desire a multitude of unfaithful children, nor rejoice in ungodly sons.
verses.comment: This verse reflects the biblical theme that quality of faith outweighs quantity in descendants, similar to 1 Samuel 2:30.

verses.text: Even if they multiply, do not be glad, unless they fear the Lord.
verses.comment: Righteousness is more important than numerous offspring; see Deut. 28:2.

verses.text: Do not trust in their life, nor set your eyes on their multitude; for one who is just is better than a thousand.
verses.comment: Echoes the value of faith and virtue over numbers, a recurring wisdom theme in Scripture.

verses.text: And it is better to die childless than to have ungodly children.
verses.comment: The spiritual legacy matters more than physical lineage; see Matt. 12:50.

verses.text: By one wise person, a city will be inhabited; but a tribe of lawless people will be destroyed.
verses.comment: The influence of a righteous individual can preserve a whole society (cf. Gen. 18:32).

verses.text: Many such things my eye has seen, and greater things than these my ear has heard.
verses.comment: The author draws on his observation and wisdom, in common with Solomon and Job.

verses.text: In the gathering of sinners, fire blazes up, and in an unbelieving nation wrath is kindled.
verses.comment: God’s judgment on communities parallels Old Testament judgments (Num. 16:35).

verses.text: He did not pardon the giants of old who were rebellious in their strength.
verses.comment: A reference to the Nephilim; illustrating God’s historical justice against evil.

verses.text: He did not spare the ancient people who lived in opposition to Him, nor those who trusted in their own strength.
verses.comment: This points to the Tower of Babel and similar narratives where pride leads to downfall.

verses.text: He did not have mercy on the people of Sodom, who perished because of their pride.
verses.comment: Judgment against Sodom and Gomorrah as a warning about communal sin.

verses.text: He did not spare even a single nation which He destroyed, nor the children of those who sinned.
verses.comment: God’s justice is impartial and consistent through all history.

verses.text: He did not pardon the six hundred thousand men on foot who gathered in stubbornness.
verses.comment: Refers to the Israelite generation that perished in the wilderness for their lack of faith.

verses.text: For if there is but one stiff-necked man, it is a wonder if he goes unpunished; for mercy and wrath both belong to Him who is mighty.
verses.comment: This verse highlights God’s perfect justice and mercy—see also Rom. 11:22.

verses.text: He pours out mercy as He sees fit, and His anger is as great as His mercy.
verses.comment: God’s mercy and justice are balanced; He responds according to His wisdom.

verses.text: A man cannot escape with his goods; the works of the wicked will be called to account.
verses.comment: This anticipates final judgment, where all deeds will be revealed (cf. 2 Cor. 5:10).

verses.text: The prayer of the humble reaches to the clouds, but the world is not safe from the vengeance that comes.
verses.comment: God hears the humble (Luke 18:13-14); humility attracts divine favor.

verses.text: He examines the depths of the abyss, and has understanding of the human heart.
verses.comment: God's omniscience means He knows not just actions, but motives.

verses.text: For the Most High knows all knowledge, and observes the signs of the times.
verses.comment: Here the ancient tradition of God's foreknowledge is restated.

verses.text: He declares the things that are past and the things that are to come, and reveals the traces of hidden things.
verses.comment: God being outside time is consistent with divine revelation; see Heb. 4:13.

verses.text: No thought escapes Him; not even a single word is hidden from Him.
verses.comment: See Matt. 12:36 for every idle word being judged; God’s omniscience is total.

verses.text: He has established mighty works; whoever will stand firm in His glory?
verses.comment: Divine majesty is both fearsome and awe-inspiring, pointing toward Christ’s glory at the Transfiguration.

verses.text: He searches out the abyss and the hearts and understands all secrets.
verses.comment: Only God can judge rightly, for He knows what is hidden (see Daniel 2:22).

verses.text: He who builds up the earth forever, and fills it with living things.
verses.comment: God as Creator is a foundational Christian doctrine; creation itself manifests divine wisdom.

verses.text: He returns the light, and brings back darkness, according to His command.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over creation echoes the opening words of Genesis.

verses.text: He sends down blessings, and they obey Him; He turned the waters into dry ground at His word.
verses.comment: Recalls the crossing of the Red Sea, a type of salvation by grace.

verses.text: His command is from the beginning; and no one can search out His works.
verses.comment: God’s eternal wisdom and the inscrutability of His providence are emphasized here.

verses.text: Who can declare His mighty acts, or endure them? For His covenant is firmly established.
verses.comment: Mentions the permanence of God’s covenant—a theme fulfilled in Christ (Luke 22:20).

verses.text: The Lord looks upon them all, and they are obedient to His word.
verses.comment: Creation’s obedience reflects the perfect service angels and saints offer to God (Heb. 1:14).

verses.text: After this, God established order on the earth, and separated the times and seasons.
verses.comment: God’s order in creation prepares the way for the divine ordering of redemption.

verses.text: They have not grown weary in their watch, nor have they neglected their tasks. Each follows His command.
verses.comment: The faithfulness of creation to God’s command is a model for human obedience; also an image of the Church as united in following the Lord's voice.
